content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" emphasizes the need to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials. Grants will be awarded to expand opportunities for scientists and researchers, as well as promote the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in the health professions. SEC. 4. SUPPORT FOR INSTITUTIONS COMMITTED TO WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities committed to health workforce development in underrepresented communities. Eligible entities include educational institutions that historically produce underrepresented minority health professionals. This includes historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, tribal colleges, and institutions with programs to recruit and retain minority health professionals. Entities eligible for grants must retain underrepresented minority health professionals, with a significant number of enrolled participants being minorities. This includes health professional associations and institutions located in communities with predominantly minority populations. Funds received must be used to expand existing workforce diversity programs. The curr_chunk outlines various activities that can be funded to enhance diversity in workforce programs, including educational outreach, scholarships, mentoring, and leadership training. These programs aim to consider minority status as part of the qualification process. The curr_chunk discusses the reporting requirements for grantees who receive funding for workforce diversity programs. It also defines "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" and authorizes appropriations for the program from 2015 to 2020. Eliminating disparities in maternity health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will work to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes by conducting research on determinants, improving performance measurement infrastructure, and expanding access to services that enhance maternity care quality and outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services aims to reduce disparities in maternity care for vulnerable populations by establishing a demonstration project in up to 8 states to compare and implement effective interventions. States will be selected based on specified regions, populations served, and criteria to ensure representation of affected communities and testing of various intervention models. The demonstration project aims to reduce disparities in maternity care by implementing effective interventions in up to 8 states. The project will involve consultation with local provider organizations and will run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. States participating will report data to the Secretary for monitoring purposes. Grants may be provided for data collection and evaluation. The Secretary will monitor project outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care. A report on the project results must be submitted to Congress by December 31, 2020. SEC. 6. HEALTH DISPARITIES EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about racial and ethnic disparities in health care. This program will disseminate scientific evidence and implement outreach strategies to reduce these disparities. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program to address disparities related to various factors such as race, ethnicity, age, disability status, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation. This program aims to disseminate research findings, raise awareness about linguistic and cultural barriers, and emphasize the importance of providing language access services to individuals with limited-English proficiency. The program aims to address disparities related to factors such as race, ethnicity, age, disability status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation. It includes data collection, educational initiatives for healthcare providers, and assessing program impact. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020.
